question:
Title: Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis (S303) at George Brown College

Program Overview:
The Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis (HBBA) is a full-time 5-semester undergraduate program, followed by a 14-week unpaid field experience term. This accelerated degree program is designed for students who have completed at least two years of an approved Behavioural Science Technology or Technician program. The HBBA program focuses on the application of principles of behaviour analysis to various settings, including education, healthcare, and community services.

Program Information:
- Program Name: Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis
  Code: S303
  Credential: Honours Bachelor's Degree
- Method of Study: Full-time
- Duration: 5 semesters + 14 week Field Experience term (Unpaid)
- Starting Months: May
- Domestic Tuition: $10,420.00 *
- International Tuition: $29,152.00 *
- Centre: Health Sciences
- School: Health & Wellness
- Location: Waterfront Campus
- Experiential Learning: 14-week placement in the summer before semester 7
- Fall 2023 Delivery: On campus (Semester 5)
- Winter 2024 Delivery: Hybrid (Semesters 6 and 8)
- Program Availability: Open for Spring 2024

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic: $10,420.00 per year
- International: $29,152.00 per year

*Please note that these tuition fees are subject to change and it is recommended to check with George Brown College directly for the most up-to-date information.

Contact Information:
For more information about the Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis program at George Brown College, please visit their website or contact them using the following details:

Website: Available in Program Menu
Email: [behaviouranalysis@georgebrown.ca](mailto:behaviouranalysis@georgebrown.ca)
Phone: (416) 415-2000 ext. 3874
Address: 51 Dockside Square, Toronto, ON M5A 0B4, Canada.?

context:
Extracted Information:

1. George Brown College offers an Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis (S303) degree program.
2. Eligibility for the program includes students who have completed two years of the Behavioural Science Technology (C116) advanced diploma program or graduated from the Behavioural Science Technician (C146) diploma program.
3. Students will go through a bridge semester during spring/summer (semester 4).
4. The degree program focuses on Applied Behaviour Analysis (ABA), which is used to modify behaviour in a desirable way.
5. ABA can be applied to populations with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), brain injury, dementia, developmental disabilities, addiction, and mental health disorders.
6. The degree program consists of three main components:
   - Component 1: Behavioural assessment
   - Component 2: Developing an effective plan based on the assessment results
   - Component 3: Ongoing evaluation of components one and two
7. The research component is a foundational aspect of the program, with students learning how to prepare an applied research proposal during semesters 5 and 6, and conducting the research during the Fall semester of their fourth year.
question:
George Brown College provides an Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis (S303) degree program for eligible students. Eligibility is granted to students who have completed two years of the Behavioural Science Technology (C116) advanced diploma or graduated from the Behavioural Science Technician (C146) diploma program. The bridge semester occurs during spring/summer (semester 4).

The degree focuses on Applied Behaviour Analysis (ABA), which aims to modify behaviour in a positive manner for populations with various conditions such as Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), brain injury, dementia, developmental disabilities, addiction, and mental health disorders. The program is divided into three main components:

1. Behavioural assessment: Identifying the problematic behaviour through observations, interviews, and other relevant data sources.
2. Developing an effective plan based on the assessment results: Creating an individualized intervention plan tailored to the client's needs and goals.
3. Ongoing evaluation of components one and two: Regularly monitoring the progress of clients and making necessary adjustments to the intervention plan as needed.

The research component is a crucial aspect of the program, with students learning how to prepare an applied research proposal during semesters 5 and 6, followed by conducting the research in the Fall semester of their fourth year.?

context:
The Association for Behavior Analysis International (ABAI) has verified the following courses toward the coursework requirements for the Board Certified Assistant Behaviour AnalystÂ® examination:
- Applicants need to meet additional eligibility requirements and demonstrate they can reside in an authorized country before they can be eligible to take the examination.
- The degree program helps prepare students to become leaders in behavior analysis.
- Graduates of the program have become leaders in fields such as forensic mental health, autism spectrum disorder, and acquired brain injury.
- The intensive program is suitable for data-driven students who enjoy analyzing patterns and working with challenging behaviors.
- Core courses focus on five areas of learning: behavioral science theories, principles and methods; special populations; psychology; research methods/statistics; ethics, professionalism and leadership.
- Graduates of approved Ontario college behavioral science technology advanced diploma programs with a 3.0 GPA or higher are eligible to enter a bridging pathway that leads to the fourth year (semester 7) of the Honours Bachelors of Behaviour Analysis (S304) degree program.
- External applicants from other institutions will be assessed for advanced standing on a case-by-case basis.
- The contact email for Program Co-ordinator Don Togade is Don.Togade@georgebrown.ca.
- As of July 2024, the profession of applied behavior analysis in Ontario will come under the jurisdiction of the College of Psychologists and Behaviour Analysts of Ontario.

No information was extracted regarding any specific program offered by the college.
question:
George Brown College offers an Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis (S304) degree program that can be completed in four years, including a bridging pathway for students with approved advanced diplomas from Ontario colleges. The program covers five areas of learning: behavioral science theories, principles and methods; special populations; psychology; research methods/statistics; and ethics, professionalism and leadership.

Graduates have gone on to become leaders in fields such as forensic mental health, autism spectrum disorder, and acquired brain injury. The intensive program is suitable for data-driven students who enjoy analyzing patterns and working with challenging behaviors. Starting in July 2024, the profession of applied behavior analysis in Ontario will come under the jurisdiction of the College of Psychologists and Behaviour Analysts of Ontario.

External applicants from other institutions may be assessed for advanced standing on a case-by-case basis. For more information, contact Program Co-ordinator Don Togade at Don.Togade@georgebrown.ca.?

context: The College of Psychologists and Behaviour Analysts of Ontario offers a Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis fast-track degree program. In the final year of the program, students participate in a 14-week unpaid field experience term between semesters 6 and 7 to conduct a research thesis. Students will be supported by a field coordinator during placement preparation and interviews. ABA practitioners may find various career opportunities such as assessment, development and implementation of skill acquisition programs, functional assessment of challenging behaviours, behaviour management plans, data collection and analysis, case management, autism spectrum disorders consultant, behaviour technician, behaviour therapist, behavioural consultant, behavioural specialist, instructor therapist, recreational therapist, residential support worker, transition co-ordinator, and vocational support worker. Graduates of the program have pursued master's degrees in Applied Behaviour Analysis, Applied Disability Studies, counselling psychology at Brock University, The Chicago School of Professional Psychology, Missouri State University, Western University, University of British Columbia, and Yorkville University. Additionally, graduates interested in working in long-term care facilities can consider applying to the Interprofessional Complex and Long-Term Care (S417) postgraduate certificate program, which is a two-semester program where students learn to coordinate and manage an interprofessional healthcare team of complex and long-term care professionals.
question: It seems that you are describing the Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis (HBBA) degree program offered by Brock University in Ontario, Canada, and the various career opportunities for graduates in the field of Applied Behaviour Analysis (ABA). The HBBA program is unique as it offers a fast-track option where students complete a 14-week unpaid field experience term between their sixth and seventh semesters. Upon completion of the degree, graduates can pursue various career opportunities in ABA such as assessment, development, and implementation of skill acquisition programs, functional assessment, behaviour management plans, data collection and analysis, case management, autism spectrum disorders consultant, behaviour technician, behaviour therapist, behavioural consultant, behavioural specialist, instructor therapist, recreational therapist, residential support worker, transition coordinator, and vocational support worker. Some graduates may also pursue master's degrees in related fields such as Applied Behaviour Analysis, Applied Disability Studies, counselling psychology, or long-term care administration. Overall, the HBBA program at Brock University provides students with a strong foundation to launch successful careers in the field of ABA and make a positive impact on individuals with developmental disabilities and other complex needs.?

context:
The college offers an applied degree with a seven-year term starting July 21, 2015. Students admitted during this period are required to complete the program within a reasonable time frame.

Special requirements for students include:
- Completing mandatory pre-placement health form requirements and submitting proof of medical records, police vulnerable sector checks, Standard First Aid certificates, CPR level HCP certificates, annual flu shots, and mask fit tests by given deadlines to ParaMed.
- Meeting the requirements to ensure protection of clients and vulnerable populations.
- Completing a Police Vulnerable Sector Check renewed every year.
- Paying for all costs associated with the overall health requirements.

The police vulnerable sector check process can take two to three months, but may take up to four to eight months under certain circumstances. It is required to protect the clientele of placement partner agencies, who are considered "vulnerable persons" under the law.
question:
It seems that in order to complete the Practical Nursing program at Conestoga College, students must fulfill certain requirements related to their health and criminal background checks. These include:

1. Completing mandatory pre-placement health form requirements and submitting proof of medical records, police vulnerable sector checks, Standard First Aid certificates, CPR level HCP certificates, annual flu shots, and mask fit tests by given deadlines to ParaMed.
2. Meeting the requirements to ensure protection of clients and vulnerable populations.
3. Completing a Police Vulnerable Sector Check renewed every year.
4. Paying for all costs associated with the overall health requirements.

The police vulnerable sector check process can take anywhere from two to three months, but may take up to four to eight months under certain circumstances. It is required to protect the clientele of placement partner agencies, who are considered "vulnerable persons" under the law.

It's important for students to plan ahead and allow sufficient time to complete these requirements before starting their program, as failure to meet them may result in delays or being unable to begin the program at all.?

context:
Students are required to provide a clear Police Vulnerable Sector Check for field or clinical placements. Those unable to do so may not be able to complete the program and will jeopardize their progress. The fees for the police record check vary and must be paid by the student (for more information, visit the Pre-placement website). Students who are not fully vaccinated against COVID-19 may not be able to complete the required field placement component of their program in the regularly scheduled time frame.

Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges. For program information, contact 416-415-5000, ext. 2367 or email hwprograms@georgebrown.ca. Related programs include Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis (S302), Autism and Behavioural Science (Postgraduate) (C405), and Behavioural Science Technician (C146). Campus tours can be booked, and applicants can sign up to receive tailored resources for their application process.

Fees for police record checks vary. Contact the Pre-placement website for more information. Students who are unable to provide a clear Police Vulnerable Sector Check or who are not fully vaccinated against COVID-19 may face challenges completing their program in the regularly scheduled time frame.
question:
Title: George Brown College - Honours Bachelor of Psychology (HBPsy) - Police Vulnerable Sector Check Requirement and COVID-19 Considerations

The George Brown College Honours Bachelor of Psychology (HBPsy) program requires students to provide a clear Police Vulnerable Sector Check for field or clinical placements. The fees for the police record check vary and must be paid by the student. Students who are unable to do so may not be able to complete the program and will jeopardize their progress.

Regarding COVID-19 considerations, those unable to provide a clear Police Vulnerable Sector Check or who are not fully vaccinated against COVID-19 may face challenges completing their program in the regularly scheduled time frame.

Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges. For more information about the program and application process, contact 416-415-5000, ext. 2367 or email hwprograms@georgebrown.ca. Related programs include Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis (S302), Autism and Behavioural Science (Postgraduate) (C405), and Behavioural Science Technician (C146). Campus tours can be booked, and applicants can sign up to receive tailored resources for their application process.

Related programs: Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis (S302), Autism and Behavioural Science (Postgraduate) (C405), Behavioural Science Technician (C146).

Note: Students who are not fully vaccinated against COVID-19 may not be able to complete the required field placement component of their program in the regularly scheduled time frame.?
